Messages.Author: Omar Sherif Omar Sherif
Messages.Content: Hello Everyone, You can now register for the exam on Moses till the 29th of May. Please do so as soon as possible.  Best,  Omar

Messages.Author: Omar Sherif Omar Sherif
Messages.Content: Hello Everyone, Please find below the allocation of papers: Emergence and collapse of reciprocity in semiautomatic driving coordination experiments with humans  Shreyas Guruvanahalli Shamasundar Large language models show human-like content biases in transmission chain experiments  Marie Luise Theresia Mehner, Amin Mohamed Amin Rida Learning to solve complex tasks by growing knowledge culturally across generations  Jacopo Ceravolo, Yevheniia Strilets Superhuman artificial intelligence can improve human decision-making by increasing novelty  Leo Gabriel Paoletti Learning few-shot imitation as cultural transmission  Jannes Meyer Fine-tuning language models to find agreement among humans with diverse preferences  Mikhail Raudin Human-centred mechanism design with Democratic AI  Deniz Mert Tecimer Scaffolding cooperation in human groups with deep reinforcement learning Constantin Von Estorff  Using the Veil of Ignorance to align AI systems with principles of justice  Achim Schadrach Groﬂmann  Best, Omar

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Using Google Colab in Our Next Lecture

Messages.Author: Levin Urs Leonard Brinkmann
Messages.Content: Hi everyone, In our next lecture, we'll be using a Python notebook in Google Colab. Thereís no need to set anything up in advance, but you will need a Google account to run the Colab notebook.  We will share the link to the notebook used in the lecture on Thursday morning before the lecture. If you do not have a Google account, you can also run the notebook locally on your computer. Please let us know if you need assistance with this setup. See you on Thursday.  Best regards, Levin

Messages.Author: Omar Sherif Omar Sherif
Messages.Content: Dear All, Thanks for applying to the Machine and Behavior course, 16 students applied for the course and since the upper limit is 20, all students got accepted. The list of participants for this semester are :  Shabnam Mansurova Mathilde Paya Deniz Mert Tecimer Jannes Meyer Erik Rubinov Victor Nogueira Alves Aguiar Filipe Alexandre Fabian Borges Youssef Fettouh Ahmed Ahmed Moussa Yevheniia Strilets Shreyas Guruvanahalli Shamasundar Jacopo Ceravolo Achim Schadrach Groﬂmann Maha Diab Konstantin Pissarsky Fiorentina Alija Leo Gabriel Paoletti Looking forward to the following semester with you and see you next Thursday! Best Regards, Omar Sherif

Messages.Author: Shabnam Mansurova
Messages.Content: Hi everyone, I wanted to clarify some stuff about the research proposal and final presentation, which is going to be around 8 minutes. Are they both due next week? Meaning 15ñ21 July? Also, if so, will everyone be able to present within the given 90-minute lecture? Or should we record ourselves presenting and share the video or the link to it until the deadline? Lecture 1 pdf did not clarify the procedure with extensive details. Can you please do so via replying or in tomorrow's lecture? Best Wishes, Shabnam

Messages.Content: Hi, Unfortunately, I missed the last lecture. Was there anything said about the formalities or content of the research proposal?

Messages.Author: Mattia Bruno Stellacci
Messages.Content: Hello, I just came across this seminar as I am dissatisfied with another seminar I chose. I know it is somewhat late, but I was wondering whether it is still possible to join this course. The first submission doesn't seem to have expired. Thank you and regards, mattia Stellacci

Messages.Author: Mattia Bruno Stellacci
Messages.Content: As there has clearly been forum activity by the organizers of this course, multiple business days have past but no reply to my enquiry, I can conclude that it is not possible to participate. I suppose it would have been nice to get an answer regardless, as it helps my organization and maybe others wondering the same thing

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Grading and unclear tasks for the seminar

Messages.Author: Leo Gabriel Paoletti
Messages.Content: Hello,  This is the grading as shown in the first lecture slides.   I'm opening this post because the tasks to do are unclear to me, except for the second one "submitting a brief answer to standard questions about each paper ahead of the class".  Could you please elaborate on what we have to do precisely regarding the first and last task ? What could be an example or the methodology to build a research proposal ? I understood that the paper assignment that we just received concerned the final presentation of 8 minutes.  But what about the presentation that we have to do in groups of two ? When will that be decided ? I would like to balance the workload of my semester and work on this seminar early.  Have a nice day, LÈo Paoletti.

Messages.Author: Iyad Rahwan
Messages.Content: Hi Leo,  Let me clarify:  [Task 1:] This is the presentation you make in groups of 2 (or 1 if you don't have a partner) once during the regular weekly classes. These have already been allocated.  [Task 2:] These are the answers you send every week, about the week's assigned paper. You send them the night before the class.  [Task 3;] This is the final 3-page report and presentation in the final week. This does not have to be related to the paper you presented. It is a research proposal in which you suggest a new project (possibly building on the paper you presented, but could be totally different). You are free to pick the format that best conveys your ideas.

Messages.Author: Shabnam Mansurova

Messages.Content: Hi Shabnam, you do not have to since you volunteered for the first paper.

Messages.Author: Shreyas Guruvanahalli Shamasundar
Messages.Content: Hi Levin & Omar, Can you guys give us a brief description of the weekly paper seminar? Like what are we supposed to present? What aspects of the paper need to be critically questioned? What other areas of the paper need to be addressed? Thanks. Shreyas.

Messages.Author: Levin Urs Leonard Brinkmann
Messages.Content: Dear Shreyas,  Sorry for the late response. We are preparing for a conference next week, so it has been quite busy. Here is a short summary of what I would suggest based on Iyad Rahwan's remarks in the first lecture. We might come up with something more formal next week.  The objective of the presentation is to spark a discussion in the group. We also would like you to prepare to facilitate the discussion. To do so, you probably want first to present a summary of the paper.  The papers are different, but in general I would suggest structuring the summary along the basic structure of: * Motivation / Research questionsóWhat motivated the research? Which particular gap in the literature did this paper intend to close? Is there one central other work this paper references? If yes, also provide a short summary of that work. * MethodsóWhich methods were used? Prepare a short explanation of this work's most central methods. To do so, you might look into related literature, but I would avoid long excursions. If the paper has supplementary material, I highly recommend skimming these as well. Many times, these help to properly understand what has been done. I suggest focusing on what has been done and not how the authors tell the story of what has been done. * ResultsóWhat are the main results? The key here is to discuss the paper's figures.  It might then be advisable to prepare open questions that could spark a discussion. The questions can be related to the questions that all of you have to answer. However, there can also be other questions that you perceived as relevant during the preparation.  No slides are generally required, but I would advise you to prepare some, as this generally helps to structure the presentation and makes it easier for everyone to follow.  Best, Levin

Messages.Author: Shreyas Guruvanahalli Shamasundar
Messages.Content: Thank You!

Messages.Author: Shreyas Guruvanahalli Shamasundar
Messages.Content: Hi, Where can I see the questions? I only see an option to submit the answers. Shreyas.

Messages.Author: Omar Sherif Omar Sherif
Messages.Content: Dear Shreyas,  You can find the questions in slide 5 in the first lecture.  Best,  Omar

Messages.Author: Shreyas Guruvanahalli Shamasundar
Messages.Content: Hi, How can I read the first week papers/articles? I googled them but couldn't get access to read them. I'm talking about the following: Rahwan, Iyad, et al. "Machine behaviour." Nature 568.7753 (2019): 477-486. Brinkmann, Levin, et al. "Machine culture." Nature Human Behaviour (2023): 1-14. Bonnefon, J. F., Rahwan, I., & Shariff, A. (2023). The moral psychology of Artificial Intelligence. Annual Review of Psychology, 75.  Thanks. Shreyas.

Messages.Content: Dear Shreyas,  You can find them now in the papers folder.  Best,  Omar

Messages.Author: Zeynep Kaya
Messages.Content: Hey,  Before the ISIS page not here, I sent an e-mail to get information about the course. I received information about a conference, not a course. I'm confused for this reason. I want to take this course since 16 people applied for the course and there is still room. How can I take the class?  Zeynep

Messages.Author: Levin Urs Leonard Brinkmann
Messages.Content: Hi Zeynep, I am sorry to hear, that you got misleading information. We have a conference upcoming with the same name. Given that there are still places, you are welcome to join. We added you to the list of participants. Best, Levin
